tooltip.help.general.1: §aCalculation§b is done using the §aback signal§b and the §ahighest side signal§b.§r
tooltip.help.general.2: §bThe output value can be §alocked§b (prevent scrolling) by holding §5[%2$s§5]§b and using §5[%3$s§5]§b with a redstone torch in hand (analog or vanilla).§r
tooltip.help.general.3: §bTo select the power output, hold §5[%1$s§5]§b and use §5Scroll Wheel§b.§r
tooltip.help.general.3_alternate: §bTo select the power output, use §5Scroll Wheel§b (you can limit this action by binding a key).§r
tooltip.help.general.4: §bYou can hide the redstone dot on this block by using §5[%3$s§5]§b with a redstone torch in hand (analog or vanilla).§r
tooltip.help.general.5: §bYou can disable inputs by using §5[%3$s§5]§b with a redstone torch in hand (analog or vanilla)§r
tooltip.help.shift.adder:
§bExact inverse of the §aRedstone Comparator§b.

In '§6Compare§b' mode, it will test if the §aback signal§b is less than or equal to the §ahighest side signal§b ( §a<=§b ).

In '§6Add§b' mode, it will add the §aback signal§b to the §ahighest side signal§b (up to §c15§b).§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_and:
§bRuns the binary operation And ( §a&§b ) for the two input signals.

%1$s
tooltip.help.shift.analog_nand:
§bRuns the binary operation Nand ( §a!&§b ) for the two input signals.

%1$s
tooltip.help.shift.analog_or:
§bRuns the binary operation Or ( §a|§b ) for the two input signals.

%1$s
tooltip.help.shift.analog_nor:
§bRuns the binary operation Nor ( §a!|§b ) for the two input signals.

%1$s
tooltip.help.shift.analog_xor:
§bRuns the binary operation XOr ( §a^§b ) for the two input signals.

%1$s
tooltip.help.shift.analog_xnor:
§bRuns the binary operation XNOr ( §a!^§b ) for the two input signals.

%1$s
tooltip.help.shift.analog_cell:
§bMemory cell that can store an analog signal.

In '§6Set§b' mode, it will constantly update and store the §aback signal§b as long as there is a §asignal provided on the side§b.

In '§6Reset§b' mode, it will constantly update and store the §aback signal§b (if greater than §c0§b). Any §asignal supplied on the side§b will reset output to §c0§b.§r
tooltip.help.shift.better_comparator: §bA glorified §aVanilla Comparator§b which works on §91 tick pulses§b. The §asides§b can read signals from even more sources (example: a lever).§r
tooltip.help.shift.checker:
§bIn '§6Equal§b' mode, it checks if the §aback signal§b is §aexactly equal§b to the §ahighest side signal§b. 

In '§6Different§b' mode, it checks if the §atwo signals§b are different from one another.

§aAlways outputs the same signal strength received from back signal with successful check.§r
tooltip.help.shift.delayer:
§bDelays the §ainput signal§b by §91, 2, 3, or 4 ticks§b, without changing the §cstrength§b or length (§9duration§b) of the signal.

Has a §65th mode§b that will delay the §ainput signal§b using the §ahighest side signal§b ( §9+1§b ).§r
tooltip.help.shift.demuxer:
§bChecks for bit §c1, 2, 4, or 8§b from the §aback signal§b.

Has a §65th mode§b where the tested bit is selected by the §ahighest side signal§b (§c1§b-> bit 1, §c2§b-> bit 2, §c3§b-> bit 4, §c4§b-> bit 8).§r
tooltip.help.shift.edge_detector:
§bIn '§6Rising Edge§b' mode, it emits a §91-tick pulse§b when the §aback signal§b is increased.

In '§6Falling Edge§b' mode, it emits a §91-tick pulse§b when the §aback signal§b is decreased.§r
tooltip.help.shift.shifter:
§bIn '§6Shift Up§b' mode, it shifts any bit(s) up by the §ahighest side signal§b.

In '§6Shift Down§b' mode, it shifts any bit(s) down by the §ahighest side signal§b.

Example: In '§6Shift Up§b' mode, with a §aside signal§b of §c1§b, the §aback signal§b of §c6§b would output §c12§b.§r
tooltip.help.shift.signal_generator:
§bGenerates a signal sequentially §9every tick§b.

§6Sequence§b will only advance while §apowered (from the back§b).

In '§6Saw§b', '§6Inverted Saw§b', '§6Triangle§b' and '§6Random§b' mode, the §aoutput signal§b will be between §c0-15§b while not powered from the sides.
If §apowered from the sides§b, the signal will stay within a set range (§abetween the lowest side signal and highest side signal, inclusive§b).

In '§6Square§b' mode, the time between oscillation will be equal to the §ahighest side signal §9+ 1 tick§b.

In '§6Sine§b' mode, the number of degrees §9per tick§b is equal to the §ahighest side§b signal §c+ 1§b.§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_redstone_torch: §bWorks just like a normal redstone torch but can have a specific §aoutput value§b set.§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_button: §bWorks just like a normal stone button but can have a specific §aoutput value§b set.§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_lever: §bWorks just like a normal lever but can have a specific §aoutput value§b set.§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_redstone_block: §bWorks just like a normal redstone block §a(can be moved)§b but can have a specific §aoutput value§b set.§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_redstone_lamp: §bWorks just like a normal redstone lamp but with §evariable light levels§b relative to the §credstone signal §areceived§b.§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_jukebox: §bThis jukebox has an §6inventory§b consisting of 15 spaces for music discs only. Depending on the §credstone signal §areceived§b, it will play a different music disc.§r
tooltip.help.shift.instrument_swapper_bl: §bUsed to hot-swap noteblock §6instrument§b without replacing a block. Has an §6inventory§b consisting of 16 spaces, you can place any block or head that has a specific instrument or sound for noteblocks in those slots. §cSignal strength§b determines which inventory slot is used (§c0-15§b).§r
tooltip.help.shift.analog_note_block:
§bThis note block plays a §fsound§b with the pitch dependent on the §csignal strength§b.

§aRight-clicking§b the block will switch between ranges '§6high§b' and '§6low§b'.§r
tooltip.help.shift.enriched_redstone:
§bThis redstone dust is mixed with conductive metals to improve §aefficiency§b and transport §adistance§b.

Loses §cone signal strength§b every §f4 blocks§b instead of every §f1 block§b.§r
tooltip.help.shift.perfected_redstone:
§bThis redstone dust is considered to be an alloy of conductive materials bound together (through sheer heat).

§cComplete signal strength retention§b (§fup to 32 blocks§b).§r
tooltip.help.shift.keyboard_item: §bThis item can be bound to most analog power generators (ex: Analog Redstone Block, Target Block, etc...) and will send keyboard/MIDI inputs as a redstone signal (you can bind up to 15 signals to 15 keys). Can be put on a lectern with a right click (shift rightclick the lectern to pick it back), then clicking the lectern will allow you to use the keyboard.§r
tooltip.help.ctrl.keyboard_item: §bTo bind a key and/or MIDI device, first open the GUI via shift rightclick in air, click on the bottom butons to bind keys to redstone signals. The top part of the GUI is used to bind your MIDI device. To bind to a power source, rightclick the source (will tell you if successful or invalid block), shift rightclick an invalid block to clear the binding. To use non-MIDI keys, you first need to toggle the item on via rightclick in air.§r
book.sculk_vibrations.creative_tab_help: Crafted by combining a 'Book and Quill' with a 'Sculk Sensor' or 'Calibrated Sculk Sensor' (the sensor will not be consumed).
